sentences.sentence: Readers express frustration and anger against the unvaccinated.

Also: Alex Azar's turnabout; diplomacy and Afghanistan; why investment in China is a bad idea.To the Editor:Re “Unvaxxed, Unmasked and Putting Our Kids at Risk,” by Jessica Valenti (Opinion guest essay, Aug. 2):Thank you, Ms. Valenti, for advocating for our children who are still too young to be vaccinated.

As a New York City elementary-school teacher, I am also infuriated that many teachers and school staff still remain unvaccinated.Next month, when the city's public schools fully resume in-classroom learning, elementary students will be walking into buildings with many unvaccinated adults.
As a parent and educator, I am appalled.
Parents should be made aware of the teacher's vaccination status.

Then, parents can make an informed choice about whether they prefer to have their child in a classroom with a vaccinated educator.I am also worried that our immunocompromised students will be at risk.

A vaccine mandate for school staff must be in place to protect our children.As we all know, schools are superspreaders of all kinds of germs, and we have a moral obligation as educators and concerned citizens to do what is right for our kids.
My heart goes out to you and your daughter.
Let's continue to advocate for the under-12 population who rely on us to be their voice!Nancy LehmanScarsdale, N.Y.To the Editor:I share the anger and rage of Jessica Valenti.
When anti-vaxxers scoff, saying, “We are healthy,” I would add, “So far.” How many of them after being infected with the virus, and near death, have said they wish they had been vaccinated?
What if their own young children succumb to Covid?Wise people learn from others' mistakes.
If all adults are vaccinated, children would be more protected until they have access to the vaccine.Maybe we cannot force anti-vaxxers to sit down and get jabbed with a dose.
But what if the pandemic relief benefits were made available only to the vaccinated?
What if the Covid medical services were provided only to the vaccinated?
What if every employer made employment contingent on vaccination?

With no job, no government benefits and no medical services, would they still scoff at the idea of vaccination?Everyone has a price; we just need to know what it is.Yamuna DasarathyWashingtonTo the Editor:Jessica Valenti gets it exactly right with her powerful piece.

I am the mother of twin grade-school boys who, thankfully, are healthy, but I am seething with rage and want to scream into the void daily with frustration and anger at the selfishness of a sizable portion of the American populace.I live in Arizona, where thegovernor banned mask mandatesand less than 50 percent of the population is fully vaccinated.
I have no way to protect my children at school, and there is no virtual option.
What type of society do we live in where our children don't deserve to be cherished and kept safe?

Thank you, Ms. Valenti, for giving us all a voice.Anais SonderPhoenixToo Late, Alex AzarTo the Editor:Re“More Americans Need to Get a Covid Vaccine,” by Alex Azar, secretary of health and human services under President Donald Trump (Opinion guest essay, Aug. 5):It was with a combination of amusement and outrage that I read Alex Azar's belated explanation of the prior administration's efforts in the development of our Covid-19 vaccines.
Where was his voice when our now disgraced former president was downplaying the seriousness of the pandemic and undermining the efforts of the C.D.C.

at controlling it through social distancing and masks?His failure to speak out helped transform what should have been readily accepted measures into a political wedge issue that has resulted in tragic and avoidable morbidity and mortality.While he is to be commended for finally stepping forward, his essay should be recognized for what it is ᅳ a desperate effort to rehabilitate his image.

The only reason we are reading it now is that he no longer has a job to lose by having it published.Jeff MoormanFairfield, Conn.The writer is a retired emergency physician.What Can We Do in Afghanistan?To the Editor:Re “We Cannot Stand By and Watch Afghanistan Collapse,” by Kai Eide and Tadamichi Yamamoto (Opinion guest essay, Aug. 3):Whenever I read about diplomacy in Afghanistan, my first question is not what should we do, but what can we do?
What leverage do we have to influence the Taliban?
What can we offer them that they do not believe they can take for themselves, and are we willing to offer that?

Or with what can we credibly threaten them?Without answers, I worry that any concern for the people of Afghanistan, no matter how heartfelt or how insightful, will come to nothing.David FoxNeedham, Mass.Don't Invest in ChinaTo the Editor:Re “Invest in China, but Without Any Illusions” (Strategies column, Sunday Business, July 25):Is Jeff Sommer serious?Your editorial page has condemned repression in Xinjiang and Tibet and the crushing of freedom in Hong Kong.

Yet Mr. Sommer says it's OK to invest in China, although “with certain reservations.”Does no one understand that investment in China helps strengthen China and enables it to go ahead with genocide and freedom-crushing while ignoring complaints from the free world?Clyde PrestowitzPotomac, Md.The writer, a former official in the Reagan and Clinton administrations, is the author of “The World Turned Upside Down: America, China and the Struggle for Global Leadership.”PHOTO:    (PHOTOGRAPH BY Lu Zhang FOR THE NEW YORK TIMES)

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
